p: The light brown apple moth, E. postvittana (Walker 1863) (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae), is a leafroller pest native to southeastern Australia, including Tasmania [ 30]. The species invaded Western Australia, New Zealand, New Caledonia, England, and Hawaii more than 100 years ago [ 55â€“ 57], and has been established in California since 2006 [ 58, 59]. It poses a significant threat to agricultural production in the United States because it feeds on more than 360 host plants, including economically important fruits such as apple, pear, citrus and grapes [ 30, 31, 60]. For example, an economic risk analysis of E. postvittana to four major fruit crops (apple, grape, orange, and pear) in CONUS estimated an annual mean cost of US$105 million associated with damage to crops and control, quarantine, and research [ 60]. The CAPS program at APHIS conducts annual surveys for E. postvittana at various counties across CONUS.
